awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Samuel Rudy is "Reliability metrics and physical constraints for the application of neural networks to dynamical system." The host institution for the fellowship is Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Themistoklis Sapsis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project outcomes report covers award ID 1902972, a Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship awarded in 2019. The funding period for this award was September 2019 - August 2020 and September 2021 - April 2022.  During these periods, the PI conducted research in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.  The one year interuption was spent in the same department with seperate funding.

Intelectual Merit
This project studied the utility and limitations of machine learning, and in particular neural networks and deep learning, to problems in physical sciences and engineering. These techniques use measured data to infer properties of or build predictive models for physical phenomena such as fluid flow or the behavior of mechanical systems. This award funded research yielding several advances.  One project studied the use of Bayesian linear regression to problems in system identification, and in particular to the correct identification of a set of 'active' explanatory terms for the dynamics of a particular time series. Subsequent research developed a method for characterizing the interaction between an oscillating submerged flexible cylinder and the flow field surrounding it using machine learning.  Finally, methods for fitting neural networks to datasets with rare, but important, events were studied and shown to outperform standard methods for quantification of extreme events.

Broader Impact
Work from this project may further the ability of scientists in the fields of dynamical systems and rare events to better apply methods from machine learning to problems in a broad set of subdomains. A critical component of academic work is also fostering the growth of aspiring scientists.  The PI is very grateful to have had the opportunity to give several lectures and to have worked with several graduate students while a postdoctoral fellow.


Last Modified: 04/26/2022
Modified by: Samuel Rudy
